Entry.1:
of August, I threw in my lot Army and ring

Visited Jim & Mary took Elsie with me
Entry.2:
to Rookwood Hospital on visit with Jack Elsie Muriel Bob 

(32B) Mess Table

a good lot of Chaps Jack Hutton President

On the 23 12 15 I was appointed chief of canteen at R.A.S Ground Moore Park Sydney by the Camp Commandant Captain Conway

Milk and Ice cream Tea and Pie

Paddy Owen known A.I.F as His Reverence
Entry.4:
By the seaside

Ivan Ivanovitch AIF

Russia
Entry.5: Colombo Suez Canal Port, Said & Tel El Kebir
Entry.6: Star of England Twin Screws 11,000 Tons
Entry.7: Sneaked out to Botany to see Mue
Entry.9:
Out with Elsie God Bless her

CAMPS

R.A.S GROUND

TEL EL KEBIR

ETAPLES

In France but my mind is way back in Australia

G.G.M.B

SONGS WE SOLDIERS SING, WHEN WEARY

AT LEAST THE FOLLOWING ARE THE TUNES. I LET GO - 

MY. ROSARY (With memories of Grace Knight)

SWEET ADELINE

I. WONDER WHO'S KISSING HER NOW

THOUGH YOUR HEART MAY ACHE AWHILE NEVER MIND

O GOD OUR HELP IN AGES PAST

KYRIE 'A' ELISON

1917

At Albert, getting ready for fight

Now at Scots Redoubt, near Pozieres

Back in Sausage Valley

Looking after Nutty a big horse

Snow as painted the battlefield

And now tis hard to pick up an old land mark but Sausage. V is hard to forget

Riding around the country in quest of Quaker Oats

By jolly jack aint it cold

On picket, a lonely job
Entry.10: Left Sydney on a flying visit to say good bye
Entry.12:
Down on the farm with the good folks

Carnsdale, the place I will see at the end
Entry.13: Left Corowa, farewell to a good old town
Entry.14: Neath bushland skies a night to be remembered six on a log
Entry.15:
My Birthday

This book was given to me by Blue eyed Nellie Breen
Entry.16: Left Balldale perhaps for ever perhaps not
Entry.17: Arrived in Sydney after a good trip.
Entry.18: Returned to camp ready for the front
Entry.19:
Muriel Elsie Jack Bob

A good day out

Elsie Nell and Muriel

3 of the best
Entry.21: Review in the Domain G. General took the salute
Entry.25:
All Well aboard the Star of England

Somewhere in the Bight
Entry.26:
First church parade

Man fell down hold

Star of England a good ship
Entry.27: Still plodding along three days since we saw land
Entry.28: Same as yesterday Water, water, picked land up late in evening
Entry.29: A week out, growing monotonous beautiful weather, everything O.K
Entry.30:
Good Bye Australia

Fighting tonight for Leightweight Championship
Entry.31: Pay day. Put up a good go last night, cheers & laughter at my antics in the ring
Entry.32: Sports to day tug of war was beaten on points in the final of championship
Entry.33:
Lovely day we are now about 3,400 from Sydney

A fortnight today I was at Manly with Elsie & Muriel
Entry.35:
Dreaming of home

Weather beautiful sea like glass
Entry.36: Fought a burly Russian to day, never got hurt
Entry.37: Some time today we cross the line
Entry.38: Nearing Colombo, it will be a welcome relief to see land, 10 days since we saw anything
Entry.39:
Silvery Sands sunny

Ceylon sighted at 8 oclock this morning
Entry.40:
Ashore at Colombo neath the sheltering palms the land of "here let me rest

It is hard to realize that I am so far from home a big step Carnsdale to Colombo
Entry.41:
Colombo "adieu"

I will call in when homeward bound
Entry.42:
Off the coast of India

Bound for the Red sea
Entry.43: Pleasent memories of Botany, three years ago to day I made my home there
Entry.44: Nothing doing, just sailing along A.1
Entry.45: This trip is good, seems as if the weather was made to order, we are fast approaching Aden, mumps fashionable I am in the fashion, thank you
Entry.46:
Sitting here on the hatchway smoking my G. B. D

Thinking of friends in the southland far across the sea
Entry.47:
Holy Communion aboard ship, sighted a speck of land after dinner

Fought a big chap from the 18th on Saturday never got hurt
Entry.48: Past a steam first since Cololmo
Entry.49: Sighted Arabia this morning entered the Red Sea tonight
Entry.50: Red Sea very warm but not to bad
Entry.51:
Passed the islands (12) known as the Apostles
 

Barren and desolate I by the lighthouse
Entry.52: The best day of the trip a real Aus spring day I felt kind of homesick when I thought of a spring day at Carnsdale
Entry.53:
The journey almost over we are now in the Gulf of Suez. Good Luck I am not sorry

The end of a perfect trip
Entry.54:
Disembarking today after a very pleasent voyage, farewell Star of England A15

Sat 8th When this far from Suez on the voyage home, I will get down on my knees & PRAY
Entry.55: Never got off at Suez got into marching kit orders came along to proceed to Port Said Now going through Suez Canal
Entry.56: Arrive at Port Said yesterday disembarking this morning lovely weather, happy & glad
Entry.57: Tel-El-Keber our camp on the desert, nice weather got here last evening
Entry.58:
Sun Sand Sin Soldiers

Flys Fleas Flags Fatigues

Camels Canals & Coons

Thats Egypt
Entry.59: Life here not to bad but the dust or sand storm was a buggar
Entry.60: Taking the place of horses 10 of us hooked up to a water waggon dragging it, 10 miles
Entry.61:
Sighing and almost Crying, cursing and then smiling for I took this job on, with my eyes open

Tel El Keber the scene of a famous battle Britons v Egyptians trenches & bones still visible
Entry.62:
Hot day but cold night

A hard bed but a contented mind cheer up Jack tis a long lane with out turn
Entry.63: TEL. EL. KEBIR monotonous but "oh damn it all it could be a lot worse
Entry.64: Writing to Muriel cabling to Elsie two darlings of whom I am always thinking
Entry.65: I like the nights for then I can sleep and forget all about the job of WAR
Entry.66: Good Friday on the desert "ah" well let us hope Australia next G. F
Entry.67: Doncaster Day I wonder how those bookies done
Entry.68: I count them one by one my socks my socks 15 beautiful pair, to good to wear, so carefully folded they lie in my kit bag tis eight weeks today since I wore a sock and my feet are in good fettle
Entry.69: SYDNEY CUP. DAY Usually (with me) a day of gambling so not to be out done I will x50Pt a chance at 2 up
Entry.70: Anzac Day, very warm, was put by in good fashion, washing wishing whistling & walking cheers Jack
Entry.71: Warmer still, but it agree's with me, like Johnny Walker I'm still going strong
Entry.72: I am getting well fed and I eat a hell of a lot getting stout and feel very fit
Entry.73: Just before breakfast the band played "Just for tonight. I felt sorry for awhile & then began to sing. Australia
Entry.74: Pinched a bottle of J Walker and made life jolly with the glowworms
Entry.75:
Cairo the city of sin & shame, the most degrading sights of the universe I never wish to witness again

Nellie Breen just a lass from Riverina and although in Cario my heart is with her
Entry.76: 10th Reinf 17th Batt Ellis Skinner the first of above company to depart to the great unknown R.I.P
Entry.77: I hardly know what to jot down, for today I am here right in the mess officers mess writing letters
Entry.78: Strolling across the desert with Letty good company for Letty is a Terrier
Entry.79: I wonder, yes, I wonder where she is who she's with and what they are doing, good thoughts
Entry.80: I have a letter from Elsie, poor little girl never mind old girl boys will be boys and go fighting
Entry.81: 10 years ago I arrived in Sydney for the 1st time and made my home at Randwick Jockey. Jack
Entry.82:
I have come to the conclusion that Egypt is the best washer-woman country in the globe dry in 2 hrs and the sun draws the dirt out

A sunny Sunday in Sunland, with a merry mind memories of Manly and my maid ELSIE
Entry.83: This is how I feel about things arse up but I suppose I will soon land on my feet and carry on indepentedly
Entry.84: Beer, beer glorious beer had a bottle today beer on the desert is indeed glorious off the ice
Entry.85: Nine weeks since I left home, not very long ago but it seems like a month of Sunday
Entry.86: I Never felt better nor thirstier talk about dry, why my throat is like a drought
Entry.87: Life is sweet when sweetness is on the menu, out here its slow, sour, stuffy and sad
Entry.88: Believe me I'm looking for a war but I guess and calculate there's no war on about T.E.K
Entry.89:
575 art though weary art though languid

575 dear brethryn let us sing

In Cairo again beastly place
Entry.90: Same old game early to bed and early to rise feeling A1
Entry.91: We shifted camp, only a mile away but it was a buggar very hot 120 in the coolest place
Entry.92: Hot as love nine days old it dont affect me Gunga din about me
Entry.93:
Drunk on the desert gin and need water

laugh, I did laugh
Entry.94:
Good Bye for a while to the good old 10th 

Jackie the first man of that brigade to leave for the firing line
Entry.95: Aboard the Cunard liner S.S Ivernia, at Alexandria left T.E K last night at 7 minutes past 10 still going strong, feeling sleepy
Entry.96:
Bound for France, left Alex. This morning, a destroyer on the port side with cruiser in the distance, Manly to the Mediteranean a long way

I am getting nearer to this "ere" war" by jove - yes for we have to wear life belts, night and day
Entry.97: Blue Skys Blue Sea"s everything beautiful so far the whole business as been a picnic
Entry.98: Malta our next Port you made me do it" a horrible dream, and so real, a returned soldier and a girl, Sunday. S S Ivernia
Entry.99: All that I now possess is what I stand up in some friend took both my bags good bye to my beautiful socks
Entry.100: Standing at our posts waiting to be torpedoed Very pleasent; I dont think, nearly to France
Entry.101:
Marsailles, looks alright, we are just going in time 4.30 A M 

Very glad to be here for I am not to kean of the water, Balldale, 3 months ago
Entry.102:
France beautiful France

I am now travelling through some of the most magnificent country imaginable tell you all about it S.O.D
Entry.103:
God guide me home, to tell my loved ones of this trip, still in the train bound for Paris & then Bolounge

The French girls are like our own pretty sweet good sociable and they like the boys
Entry.104: France a perfect fairy land, still in the train and not far from the sound of the big guns feeling OK. N E M
Entry.105: Visited the Bull-ring full marching order and the Bull turned out to be a bloody cow
Entry.106: Eyes right eyes left, thirty miles from the firing line bully beef bed and biscuit long marches and short sleeps, 3 hours from London
Entry.107:
Arms Armys Ammunition Aeroplanes Airships

Bombs Bully Biscuits & Beer parts of France
Entry.108: I am thinking to night of the girls I love ELSIE Nell Muriel Dolly distance only lends happy thoughts
Entry.109: Time passes quickly will be leaving for the trenches any day, just as well do my bit and get it over & hope for the best S.A.G
Entry.110:
Ah, me, life is a queer game one never knows what is next

Carnsdale is the place I'd like to be to day it is raining here miserable day
Entry.111: Still playing soldiers and playing the game
Entry.112: Raining like 1 thing and here we are like tea towels after a big wash up, very damp
Entry.113: Writing this in full view of the North Sea with a German air ship overhead about 2 mile high
Entry.114: Feet still warm but I hope I dont get shot, bless my heart I am game , so Cheers Jack
Entry.115: Ought a young chap risk his life to gain nothing "no certainly not
Entry.116: Pay day in France 40 Franc my lot something doing to tonight
Entry.117:
Sunday, the morning after the night before

Beer Wine Rum

"Oh mamma

Church parade and then shell Fire
Entry.118: Raining like hell marching all night and swearing like buggarerey
Entry.119: Having a spell just wandering around & wondering all sorts of things
Entry.120: Issued with rum and the boys are all shickered but of course I am sober
Entry.121: It would be a pity if I stopped a shell for theres Ellsie Muriel Dolly and Nell
Entry.122: 3 weeks to day we landed in France so far so good
Entry.123: Nothing to do only read and write slow very slow, but better than being fast and furious
Entry.124:
Good old Sunday tis the same as Monday or Tuesday to us but they dont work on Sundays in Stralia

MEMORIES

of many things to numerous to mention

Feeling very lonely with a greasy smile
Entry.125: The day after Sun. and the second day of the week, also 6 days from pay day "very interesting
Entry.126: Wish the big advance would start and then maybe the B- germans would S. UP
Entry.127: Night & the shadows falling o'er land & sea some where a voice is calling calling to me. THE BUSH LAND & ELSIE ARE CALLING
Entry.128: I think, that I will write to Nell, and tell her some of the things that are written in this book or shall I send her the lot, book and all
Entry.129: Believe me girls I am happy but I d love to be home with you
Entry.130: Pay day once more that means more beer wine and rum I have a nip but not drink
Entry.131: Give the Aust Â£ 1 each declare Berlin out of bounds and I'll bet they'll get there Same old game doing nothing but it gets slow but better than drill Beautiful day
Entry.132: I am beggared if I know a very good tale that I don't want to forget
Entry.133: I'm enjoying myself Jackie Spare Colonel
Entry.134: Assistant Censor and other little jobs
Entry.136: They ars fighting like blazes, we ll win
Entry.137: Sky one blaze of fire cannons to the left and right G Guiders
Entry.139:
bless every one at home, and S. A G me there

Doing things that I shouldent, never again

117th day from home, and the 17 week, be leaving for Aus next
Entry.140:
Fuesday 4

I was dreaming, I was dreaming, of a nice little girl sweet persons of Nellie Breen
Entry.141: All day long the big guns keep speaking and very loud at that
Entry.142: Still living in hopes, big hopes
Entry.143: I suppose you wonder where I am I m in a good safe place but it may be otherwise next week
Entry.144: Pay day more booze, but bless your heart it cheers a soldiers life
Entry.145:
Soldier boy, what are you thinking of.

I am thinking of my girls

Nell Els Muriel Dolly

All of the one class

Balldale Randwick Botany Botany
Entry.146:
On leave to Paris

P large nice place but very slow place of money ect
Entry.147: I have had a ripping time, since I joined the army doing just as I please
Entry.148: I wonder if the huns are as happy as are singing, laughing & b- the Kaiser
Entry.149: Though the day may be long, it goes forth with a song
Entry.150: With the snipers & jolly lot they are Mick Colin Arthur Jack Ray Jim all good fellows
Entry.151: A happy family the details of the 17th Batt
Entry.152:
I go to church like a little saint and sing with all my heart

Mary Jim Darcy Allen Eunice Lena Mary Edith Bridget Nelly just
Entry.153: Elsie should get my cable to day I wonder how she is and if she still thinks of me
Entry.154:
Might get a letter today big mail in

No luck - no letters ah me
Entry.155: We are making the huns sit up
Entry.156: Have a tomato, I had 4 today a real luxury
Entry.157:
God, how they are fighting

Muriel Tillsons Birthday
Entry.158: Pay day once again I wont be sorry when George V pays me off
Entry.159:
Sunday once again, and still happy

I dont care a damn, but I wish and wish
Entry.160: Off to the line full of faith
Entry.161: After 24 hours ride in train we arrive at VICNACOURT
Entry.162: You'll soon know your fate Jack the same good spirit will lead you
Entry.163: It's just like hell pure & simple
Entry.166:
Sunday, on the scene of death

Hope and pray
Entry.167: Wipe the scenes away they are awful
Entry.168: Thundering guns and flame lit skys
Entry.169: Men brave men of Aust. a heroic breed
Entry.170: How long O Lord how long
Entry.171: Elsie Dean, my girl, 12 months ago to day I made her happy
Entry.172: The boys went over last night and pushed Fritz back
Entry.173:
Sunday, and out of the fray, for a while, we lost good men

Tis a beautiful day we are camped about four miles behind the trenches
Entry.174: Billited at a town named "Warboy" had a good rest in an old stable, everything O K
Entry.175:
VAL. DE. MAISON

Jackie in wonderland resting until morn in an apple garden, tis grand after a long & dusty
Entry.176:
On the wallaby, plodding along, through wheatfields the country is similar to the Riverina district

HALLOY
Entry.177: I'm bottle green and lousey wet outside, dry inside, but I'm bearing up, I wont cry, just sigh oh! thats all
Entry.178: Its a hard life this soldiering job, but we will grin and bear it until the huns bubble bursts
Entry.179: Writing home dear old home, Randwick Botany, and that loving land of milk and honey way down south CARNSDALE
Entry.180:
The day we d meet our girls and go loving "ah sweethearts, how we will cuddle up when our guns are cast aside

The nights are like scorned love, very cold but it wont kill us for our hearts are big
Entry.181: A letter from Elsie news, of the grasswidor and the old maid it makes me "want to go home
Entry.182: Living like a winning side should live, on the best of everything chicken for dinner
Entry.183: We all go a travelling we're all on the road, we go a travelling and carrying a load. Full marching order, "Halloy" farewell
Entry.184: At home we use to sing and talk out here in France we fight and walk and swear like drunken sailors
Entry.185: On appearances, judging the homes, women, and ways of foreign lands I think Christ use to live in Australia the promised land
Entry.186: Pay day at Harponville I don't save any cash but, I find it hard to spend, "queer is it not
Entry.187:
Going back to the firing line, full of confidence with the same good spirit leading me

The hours spent with you dear hearts were moving I cannot count them out one by one although I try
Entry.188: Sitting in a once "hun" dug out (now Australian) reading a love yarn named "The Back of Beyond.(Hanley Station)
Entry.189:
We are the ragtime army

But we'll prove in a ragtime way

To Kaiser Bill & his naughty son

That we'll win the blooming day
Entry.190: In the line, and not a button on my fly twas always thus always thus they will insist in all coming off at once
Entry.191: It is not so rough as our last trip in, but quite rough enough, I am now attached to Head Qrts
Entry.192: R.U.M. dutch courage. The damn stuff makes me feel afraid, no bon for the top piece
Entry.193: "What did you do in the great war daddy" A question I hope to be asked one day in the future
Entry.194:
Over the sea far away they lie far from the land of their love. Our fallen mate's R.I.P Hades, bellum est

My friend's Trent Haigh and the good old Bulletin, the best paper on earth
Entry.196: Brigade. The field of action is now a huge puddle hole, mud and slime; Camped at Tara.
Entry.197: Ready and strong marching along. But its damn hard last time dust this time mud. Warloy again
Entry.198: It is raining like blazes, we are camped in a rat infested dwelling, but grateful shelter
Entry.199: Marching through beautiful country, as beautiful as the beauty of a woman thats done no wrong
Entry.200: "Beauval", at present our home nice place, beautiful church good beer, lovely champagne and the women are pleasing to the eye
Entry.201: Letters from Mary Elsie Nell Hilda & Muriel, a happy day Their health in champagne
Entry.202:
So long they power hast blest me sure it still will lead me on back to those I love

A chap is playing "Rememberance" it takes me far across the sea, to Botany
Entry.203:
We have had a grand time in this town, Allan Patterson Pickanice and Mac

Moving off in the morning
Entry.204: France "adeiu". We are now in Belgium at a town named Poperinghe seven miles from the famous YEPRES
Entry.205: Staying at an up to date house, sausages for breakfast with fried onions & tomatoes very good tres bon
Entry.206: With a Scotchsman (Patterson) and an Irishman (McDonell) and of course drinking
Entry.207: "Moving day" going back to the firing line after spending a good holiday still in good heart & faith
Entry.208: Ypres by moonlight was a weird sight passed the night in the ramparts of an old fort
Entry.209:
Last night we three (two Mack and Jackie) were lost on the battlefield Boy's of the Limber Lost Camped in a brick tunnel 

Chat's are sweet little crawling animals, that make me, take my shirt off four times each day
Entry.210: Life in a dungeon is monotonous, but we contrive to make it happy, with a lot of tommy rot
Entry.211: We are like Vampire's, in our nests all day and doing our dirty work at night
Entry.212:
My daddys birthday

The front here is very quite, and our list of casualtys very light

Letters from Eileen & Valerie
Entry.213: Being relieved tonight by the 23rd battalion but only for a day or two. The mysterious Whisky bottle
Entry.214: Back at the ramparts of Ypres, feeling O K and enjoying myself, to day we hold our hands out
Entry.215: Here I am with 40 Francs and without any means of spending it Today I met Lieutenant Reg Gibbons he looks well
Entry.216:
A nice quiet day, on a nice quiet front. Rather be home, it would be quite alright

Letters from Elsie, Kitty, Emma, Maggie, Miss Caro, Valerie, & Eileen a busy day
Entry.217: Raining like one thing, but thank providence, we are still at the ramparts
Entry.218: Today the germans dropped messages from their planes "WE WANT PEACE AT ANY PRICE"
Entry.219: Up we go with the best of luck taking over the trenches tonight. Good Luck
Entry.220: "Valley Cottage Sanctury Wood" my present home not much good but it is better than none
Entry.221: I must confess that my feet are cold, caused through wet boots & socks not funk
Entry.222: It is a beautiful day and I have a beautiful cold in the head
Entry.223:
Did
 What did it feel like when the bullet hit you asked the tiresome old lady and after the eloquent Anzac had told her, she complained to the matron
Entry.224: Three months for Xmas How time flies I have been 201 days, away from Australia
Entry.225: A very heavy artillery duel taking place and the shells are falling close I'm in my funk hole
Entry.226: To nights the night for our bretheren 19th are coming up to let us go back. We had a few casualtys
Entry.227: Andy Fisher was up to see the Colonel and I but the old man was out, Andy looked well
Entry.228: Living in comfort at the ramparts sleeping on a real live bed wire matress and alive with chats, but its good
Entry.229:
Now at the barracks Singing to night at the battalion concert nice stew for tea (meat beans spuds tomatoes & bovril)

Sunday Oct. 1

In a cafe with Irish English Scotch Welsh Australians and Canadians

Drunk as old Dave on a farmers picnic

This little book as been in action seven months to day Blue Eyed Nell
Entry.231: 8 hour day, and not a racecourse for miles, Had a jolly day yesterday
Entry.232: The British soldier is a good sport and the back bone of a great empire, BUT -
Entry.233: By the British officer those worthy soldiers are considered to be very inferior chaps scum of the nation
Entry.234: This bird and that bird but we're birds of a feather, and just as good as they are
Entry.235: Good Bye Ypres entraining to night for France where we are going to spend a whole months holiday
Entry.236: Last night was a fair buggar we got lost, marching for six hours, and then slept in the rain
Entry.237:
Living on a farm tis just like being at home, and I am sure that the stay will be enjoyable

Mary, nice girl, but today we move to another selection

Denice a sweet little thing of 17 summers
Entry.238: Picking potatoes with Marcella a labour of love, beleive me the girls about here are O.K
Entry.239: Vanderlyneden Farm & Winniezeele, & Steenvoorde very nice places in Flanders. I had a very happy evening last night
Entry.240:
Teaching a sweet little Flemish girl to speak English, and she is a good pupil

Doo-neeze
Entry.241: Good Bye Winniezeele, tis just like leaving home the girls were bonny
Entry.242: We are in little wooden huts, and back in Belgium, cold winds and rain. We had a long march yesterday
Entry.243: Feeling sore and stiff after playing football N S Wales versus Victoria
Entry.246: On the track again this time to an officers school near Calais A.1
Entry.247: far so good. I have been in some nasty corners, but not with standing all that Ive had a good time!
Entry.248: Arrived at St Omer last night and marched to a village named Whisque, and made our home at a monastary
Entry.249: The monastry is a fine building. 4 stories and situated in a nice park, bands ect very pleasent
Entry.250: 12 months ago today I joined the army. 365 days of pleasent cruel wierd & wonderful experiences. Still going strong
Entry.251: Sunshine & shadows the way of life, yesterday a day of sore feet, to day OK
Entry.252: The first touch of a strange winter, "oh so cold but now (dinner time) tis lovely
Entry.253: 14,000 miles from home a long long trail but it dont seem far for I am happy and feel sure of getting back
Entry.254:
9.30 Sunday morning in France is 7.30 Sun night in Aust, I wonder where they are N.E.M

I doubt that we Anzac's will stand the winter for this morning we could not feel our hands, twas bitter cold
Entry.255: At a french home in a small villiage teaching the kids the difference
Entry.256: If ever I reach home which is all I live for, I'll have some queer tales to tell
Entry.257: My poor old tunic, for 5 months, it as been a friend slept in, used for a pillow blanket towel ect and they wonder why tis shabby
Entry.258: Jocks Paddys Taffys & Biljims, birds of a feather we have some great fun in the attic
Entry.259: At Hellines, sipping wine and telling Madam'sle all about Australia
Entry.260: The war is still going on but down here we have forgotten all about it, having a good time
Entry.261:
This war so they say will sink social differences but I think not, come over here. Offficers & Privates

The work of art in this building is magnificent

To day I am having a trip to St Omer
Entry.262: Midnight in an officers mess they are all drunk and yet we privates are crimed for being so
Entry.263: A drop of spirits is all we have to make our future cheerful but we never get any, at least very seldom
Entry.265:
Sleep and forget the day will come

P.R.I 2 ARMY
Entry.266: The Duke of Connought was here today along with a lot of WHISKY complexioned generals
Entry.267: The flow of wine gin whisky ect is immence if the huns drink more well they are alway drunk
Entry.268:
Been to church, and now in an estaminat wondering how long and what the future as in store for me

Muriel a letter

Elsie likewise

Mary a cable

Oh dearie me
Entry.269: Waiting on French generals at a millitary dinner great style & pomp
Entry.270: Raining in torrents But thank the Lord I am under the roof of the Convent
Entry.271: At a town "Wizernes" with a bonny French girl by my side
Entry.272:
Fighting for the L W Champ 2 A S

Put up a good go just got beat but I received a great reception
Entry.273: Off again, in battle array, Farewell to a good home. Convent of Mercy Wisques
Entry.274:
A night in Calais had a good time in the Garden of Eden

A Railway ride in Europe can be likened unto life, you never know when it will end
Entry.275: In the city of Abbeyville now after cash hope we succeed Got 1st, 17th 18th & 28th Batt.
Entry.276: A tourist our 4th day in the train and the end not yet in sight now at Romescampis
Entry.277: Now at Albert, arrived here last night and the huns greeted us with bombs & machine G fire
Entry.278: I am as Cold as ice is stranded on the Albert station living on biscuits
Entry.279: Falling shells are making things very uncomfortable, still on the station
Entry.280: Snowing and tis very cold, but thank the Lord, I am warm & under shelter
Entry.281:
Making the best of a bleak time still waiting for the transport at Albert

The Battle front is very quite to day not a sound to be heard
Entry.282: Once more with the Battalion this time in the line, in front of Bapume. A sea of M.U.D
Entry.283: Being releived tonight by the 5th division half of the batt are away in hospital
Entry.284: The trenches and road's are what we Australians term "A fair bastard" Now at Ribemont
Entry.285: Last night I had the first genuine meal after ten days of bully & biscuits
Entry.286: A lucky day, parcel from Muriel and letters from Elsie Nell Bridge Louie, & Lottie
Entry.287: A parcel from Elsie yesterday was spent with J McCredie and Jack Levy of Corowa
Entry.288:
Mud and Rum at present the chief factor's of France 

Roast beef cabbage spuds & beans custard & apricots Sundays dinner
Entry.289: Talking to a chap from Lochart "Oh" what memories of home
Entry.290: Everything is wet and miserable & tis a hard job to be happy
Entry.292:
Batt

Bob Warren 3946

Bill Elder 3820

Jack Hutton 4141

Good naughty boys (AMIENS)
Entry.293: On the track, a long march, putting up at village "Cardinet"
Entry.294: I'm cold I'm hungry and it is Nell Breens Birthday
Entry.295: All the boys are coughing their feet are sore in fact in fact it is one huge home of illness
Entry.296:
General Legge with a hell of a big staff inspected us yesterd

Pickle my Pickle I'd love to be with YOU
Entry.297: The first good day for a long time A.1
Entry.299:
GOOD. LUCK

Elizabeth Bay
 

IT. IS

Elsie Deans 22nd Birthday
Entry.300: This war I'm afraid will get worse before it gets better
Entry.301: This is a lovely war at any rate, that is what we gather from the speeches made at home
Entry.302: But if they were out here in the muck and mire they would soon think otherwise
Entry.303:
Amiens again, the cathedral is a beautiful building

While in that House of worship I prayed for all at HOME
Entry.304: According to days paper the crops at home are spoilt by rain, uncheerful news
Entry.305: "Water, Water, every where but not a drop of Rum
Entry.306: The jottings in this book havae been writen in some queer places and at queer times
Entry.307: Par Villers Bocaye Madam V-Delahtaye "Cardonette" my French mamma
Entry.308: In despite of the conditions under which we are living I never felt better
Entry.309: Au Revior to Cardonette the best home so far in France
Entry.310:
Arrived at Franville at 2 oclock yesterday. long march

Left Franville at 9 this morning, arrived at Dernacourt for dinner S.A.G
Entry.311: Met many old pals today, from all parts of Aust. Jim Sharman was one
Entry.312: Back in the firing line at Fricourt, very cold
Entry.313: Moving higher up to a place named Montabaum. Snow & ice this morning
Entry.314: Wind and rain. Walking duckboards is a fine art
Entry.315: It is marvellous what a man can put up with, and yet be happy. A parcel from Emma. K
Entry.316:
The land of rumour's out here we never see a paper, but hear a lot of queer tales

Sunday 24
Entry.317:
another hopeless dawn but after breakfast we received our comforts 

Moving today up towards Ginchy feeling OK and still in good heart
Entry.318: "Peace on earth goodwill ect but a bombardment is now taking place. Miserable place but it could be worse
Entry.319: When I forget Xmas Night & Boxing Day, I will be down under
Entry.320: Cold, Cold & muddy his he, in fact I am like a little wild man
Entry.322: The good luck is still with me I missed the stunt in the line a Q.M
Entry.323: Wallowing in the mud like pigs but it cant last for ever
Entry.324: (Finis) I pray to the "Lord of War that the year 1917 may bring peace and that He leads me in the future as He as led me in the past. AMEN
